title-group.article-title: Robust fault detection filter using linear matrix inequalities’ approach for shaft crack diagnosis

article-meta.aff: 1Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Bialystok University of Technology, Poland
2Center for Rotating Machinery Dynamics and Control (RoMaDyC), Cleveland State University, Cleveland, Ohio, USA
3OAI/NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, Ohio, USA

author-notes.corresp: Zbigniew Kulesza, Bialystok University of Technology, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, ul. Wiejska 45C, 15-351 Bialystok, Poland Email: z.kulesza@pb.edu.pl

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Detecting cracks in rotating shafts is a challenging problem when using vibration-based diagnostics. This is due to the fact that a localized crack has a minimal influence on the global vibration response of the system. To increase sensitivity and reliability, the vibration response needs to be coupled with additional sources of information such as a mathematical model of the machine. Modern control theory techniques offer system-level mathematical models for both control and diagnostics. Focusing on the latter, a new and promising approach involves the use of unknown input observers. Such observers can be designed to employ robust fault detection filters (RFDFs) for isolating fault signatures while reducing the influence of real-world disturbances and noise. For the present study, a modified design procedure coupled with robust fault detection is utilized for shaft crack detection. The filter is designed using the linear matrix inequalities (LMI) technique. The LMI approach is applied to obtain the solution of the mixed H−/H∞ optimization problem, which arises during the synthesis of the RFDF. By reformulating the LMI conditions, the proposed RFDF design procedure is simplified and thus requires less iteration steps to find the optimal solution. A new feature of the present approach involves the application of the rigid finite element method for the formulation of the mathematical model of the rotor and the shaft crack. The numerical and experimental results confirm the advantages of the designed robust fault detection filter and its ability to detect shaft cracks. The filter is minimally sensitive to measurement noise while allowing for the identification of shallow cracks (2% or 5% deep). The cracks are manifested through the observance of very subtle vibration response changes. The results also confirm the effectiveness and accuracy of the rigid finite element modeling concerning the cracked rotor.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Shaft cracks are one of the main contributors to catastrophic machine failures. Rotating shafts, often transferring large amounts of kinetic energy, are important and responsible components of many types of machines. This includes power generation plants, aircraft engines, machine tool spindles, etc. A transverse shaft crack can develop due to excessive stresses, micro- and macro- discontinuities, temperature changes, corrosion and other mechanisms to which rotating shafts are subjected. Once initiated, the crack continues to propagate even for loads within normal limits. The crack growth rate increases radically after a certain critical depth, resulting in a very quick failure of the rotor. Such failure is accompanied with the release of large amounts of kinetic energy. As such, an early crack detection and warning system is essential for high energy rotor systems in order to assure safety and reliable operation.

Numerous reports on dynamical analysis and practical detection of rotor cracks have been published during the last few decades. Many different crack diagnosis methods have been developed (Friswell and Penny, 2002), including signal-based (Bently and Muszynska, 1986; Saavedra and Cuitino, 2002; Muszynska, 2005), model-based (Bachschmid et al., 2000; Sekhar 2004; Pennacchi et al., 2006), modal testing (Sawicki et al., 2003, 2008), as well as non-traditional (He et al., 2001; Guo and Peng, 2007; Xiang et al., 2008) techniques. Currently, the model-based fault detection methods seem to be receiving the most attention.

In model-based methods, a reliable model of the system is used to create the residual, i.e., the difference between the measured process variables and their estimates delivered by the model (Ding, 2008). The process of creating the residual is referred to as the “residual generation”. Next, the fault of interest is extracted from the residual. This process is called the “residual evaluation”. In summary, faults are identified and distinguished from system disturbances and uncertainties, and then compared to a user defined threshold at which time a decision is made concerning the health of the system (i.e., fault or no fault).

Early development of model-based diagnosis techniques for rotor crack detection involved relatively simple methods of least squares fitting in the time or frequency domains. These fits were for additional vibrations caused by equivalent loads due to a crack. Bachschmid et al. (2000) used the least squares method in the frequency domain to identify and locate different machine faults. They applied parity equations, assuming that the faults affected some of the unmeasurable inputs, while the real outputs were measured and compared with the calculated model outputs. The crack depth was evaluated by comparing the static bending moment due to the rotor weight and bearing alignment conditions, to the identified equivalent periodic bending moment that simulated the crack. Sekhar (2004) applied a similar approach by replacing the fault-induced changes in the shaft by equivalent loads in the finite element model. To identify the fault parameters, he minimized the difference between the theoretical fault model and the measured equivalent loads using a least squares algorithm. The method was only tested using numerical results from fairly simple rotor models. Pennacchi et al. (2006) extended the method and obtained good experimental model validation and crack depth identification.

Another model-based technique is referred to as “state estimation” (Patton and Chen, 1997; Isermann, 2005). This approach uses the concept of an observer adopted from the classical control systems theory. Both linear and nonlinear observers can be applied, depending on the physical properties of the monitored system. Söffker et al. (1993) suggested a method of reconstructing external disturbances by using the classical state observer for the extended rotor-bearing system. Simulations were carried out showing the theoretical success of this method, especially for reconstructing exciting forces in the form of inner forces caused by the crack. Söffker et al. calculated the relative crack compliance, which was defined as the ratio of the additional compliance caused by the crack to the undamaged compliance. In turn, a clear relationship was established between the opening and closing of the crack (and, therefore, indicating the existence of the crack). Furthermore, the quantitative assessment of crack depth was possible. Kulesza and Sawicki (2010) introduced auxiliary state variables, showing that an observer for such an augmented rotor system can generate very reliable crack estimates.

When noise affects the monitored system, stochastic observers such as Kalman filters can be used. Seibold and Weinert (1996) showed that the depth of the crack can be calculated correctly, even if the measurement information is incomplete. Loparo et al. (2000) extended the Kalman filter approach to the concept of the filter bank in order to detect and diagnose different faults in the vibration system. State estimation for crack detection was discussed by Park (2000), who used filter banks to diagnose a crack occurrence, including its depth and location.

The common problem of all model-based methods is the model uncertainty, i. e., the model–reality mismatch. As the model more closely approximates the real-world system, diagnostics become more reliable. Unfortunately, model uncertainty as well as disturbances are inevitable in industrial systems. Hence, there is a need for robustness within fault diagnostic systems. Many approaches have been proposed for robust fault detection filters (Chen and Patton, 1999; Ding, 2008), but the most common one is to use robust observers, such as the unknown input observer (Massoumnia, 1986; Chen et al., 1996; Patton et al., 1997), which can tolerate a degree of model uncertainty and, hence, increase the reliability of fault diagnosis. Using the unknown input observer, the difference between the model and the real-world system is represented by the so-called “unknown input”. As a result, the state estimate is obtained taking into account model uncertainty.

The robust fault detection filter (RFDF) is a linear unknown input observer, where the associated observer gain is selected to ensure optimal robustness to disturbances as well as sensitivity to faults (Hou and Patton, 1996). It has been widely accepted that the H∞ norm of the disturbances-to-faults transfer matrix is a good measure for disturbances rejection capability in a fault detection system. Similarly, the H− index, first introduced by Hou and Patton (1996), seems to be a very appropriate measure of the fault-detection sensitivity (Peng et al., 2005; Ding, 2008; Guo et al., 2009). Minimizing the effects of disturbances and maximizing the fault sensitivity involves the simultaneous minimization and maximization of the H∞ and H− performance indices. Hence, the RFDF design procedure can be characterized as a mixed optimization problem. A number of approaches using the mixed H−/H∞ optimization techniques have been developed including the eigen-structure assignment approach (Douglas and Speyer, 1995), the geometric method (Massoumnia, 1986), the linear matrix inequalities approach (Hou and Patton, 1996; Zhong et al., 2003; Peng et al., 2005; Wang et al., 2007; Guo et al., 2009), the genetic algorithms approach (Patton et al., 1997) and many others. The reader is referred to Ding (2008), for further details concerning the various methods.

Linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) are particularly well suited for mixed optimization problems. Originating in early 1990s (Boyd et al., 1994), the LMI approach has become an important formulation and design tool in control theory. In addition to standard robust control problems (Gahinet and Apkarian, 1994), it is also employed for multiobjective optimization and handling of model uncertainties (Hou and Patton, 1996; Zhong et al., 2003; Wang et al., 2007; Ding, 2008; Guo et al., 2009). The design of a robust fault detection filter is in its nature a multiobjective optimization between the robustness against disturbances, model uncertainty, and sensitivity to faults. As a result, the application of LMIs for such problems has received much attention.

Turning to the present study, the authors address the problem of a robust shaft crack detection filter design using LMI tools. First, the mathematical model of the rotor is discussed. The model utilizes the rigid finite element (RFE) method, which has been successfully applied to various mechanical structures, such as machine tools, cranes, ship hulls, etc. (Kruszewski et al., 1999, Wittbrodt et al., 2006). Next, the LMI formulation of the robust fault detection filter for a linear time invariant system is introduced. This is followed by the development of an iterative algorithm used to obtain the optimal solution to the mixed H−/H∞ observer design problem. The mathematical model of the rotor is then reduced and adopted for the RFDF design. A numerical analysis, together with an experimental validation are conducted to demonstrate the derived results for the designed fault detection filter.

sec.title: 2.1. Rigid finite element model of the uncracked rotor
sec.p:
The rotor used as a reference in this paper is utilized as a part of the crack detection test rig at the Center for Rotating Machinery Dynamics and Control (RoMaDyC) at Cleveland State University (Sawicki et al., 2011). The rotor consists of a shaft and a disk and is supported by two ball bearings. The main dimensions and the schematic diagram of the rotor are presented in Figure 1(a). Figure 1.
Model of the rotor. (a) Dimensions and initial division into 46 spring-damping elements, (b) secondary division into 47 rigid finite elements, (c) local coordinate system ξ, η, ζ, and local coordinate systems of individual rigid finite elements (xr,1, xr,2, xr,3) and spring-damping elements (yk,1, yk,2, yk,3).

The mathematical model of the rotor is formulated using the rigid finite element method (Kruszewski et al., 1999; Wittbrodt et al., 2006). The basic concept of the RFE method lies in the discretization of the continuous structure into several undeformable bodies called rigid finite elements. These elements are connected with massless spring-damping elements (SDEs) of linear characteristics. The motion of each RFE is considered in the local coordinate system xr,1, xr,2, xr,3 (Figure 1(c)). At a standstill the origin of the system is located at the mass center while its axes coincide with the principal axes of the RFE. Similarly, the motion of each SDE is considered in the local system yk,1, yk,2, yk,3. The axes of the system are chosen in such a way that the generalized force acting along each axis causes only a translational deformation of the SDE in a direction along the axis. Similarly, the pair of forces acting around each axis causes only a torsional deformation around the axis.

Following the rigid finite element approach the rotor has been divided into 47 RFEs and 46 SDEs (Figure 1(b)). The division runs in two steps: first the rotor is discretized into 46 elements (Figure 1(a)) and a spring-damping element (marked with a crossed circle) is placed in the middle of each element; next 47 rigid finite elements are placed between the subsequent SDEs. Each tapered element (3, 4, 40, 41) is replaced by six prismatic elements of equal length and gradually decreasing diameter (Kruszewski et al., 1999; Wittbrodt et al., 2006). The bearings are modeled using two additional spring-damping elements connecting the basis (numbered as 0) with the 2nd and with the 43rd rigid finite element (Figure 1(b)).

The vibrations of the rotor are considered in the local coordinate system ξ, η, ζ, which rotates with the rotor with its angular speed Ω around axis ζ, which at a standstill is the rotor symmetry axis (Figure 1(c)). After applying the Lagrange approach the motion equations in the rotating coordinate system, take the following form (1)Mq··+(Dd+ΩDg)q·+Kq=P where M, Dd, Dg, K are inertia, damping, gyroscopic and stiffness matrices, q is the vector of generalized displacements, and P is the vector of forces (such as gravity, unbalance, etc.) applied to the rotor.

Matrices M, K are composed of the following 6×6 blocks of inertia Mr and stiffness Kk coefficients (Kruszewski et al., 1999; Wittbrodt et al., 2006): (2)Mr=diag([mr,1mr,2mr,3mr,4mr,5mr,6])
(3)Kk=diag([kk,1kk,2kk,3kk,4kk,5kk,6])

Here, diag(v) denotes the diagonal matrix with elements of v on the main diagonal, and mr,1=mr,2=mr,3=mr, where mr is the mass, while mr,4, mr,5, mr,6 are mass moments of inertia of the r-th RFE; kk,1, kk,2, kk,3 are translational and kk,4, kk,5, kk,6 are torsional stiffness coefficients of the k-th SDE. The non-zero elements of the 6×6 gyroscopic block of r-th RFE are, as follows (Kulesza and Sawicki, 2012) (4)Dg,r(2,3)=-2mr, Dg,r(3,2)=2mr, Dg,r(5,6)=-mr,4,Dg,r(6,5)=mr,4.
To simplify the considerations, the damping matrix Dd is assumed in the following, well-known form (5)Dd=αdM+βdK, where coefficients αd and βd are taken as follows: αd=10-5, βd=0.

The generalized displacements q of the rotor are calculated using the rotating reference frame ξ, η, ζ, and then transformed to the inertial frame x, y, z (Figure 2), using the following dependency: (6)qg=Tgq where for the instantaneous time t the diagonal transformation matrix Tg is assembled using elemental coordinate transformation matrices Te, yielded as (7)Te=[0-sin(Ωt)cos(Ωt)0-cos(Ωt)-sin(Ωt)100]
Figure 2.
Rotor crack section in inertial and rotating coordinates.
Vector P of forces applied to the rotor is composed of gravity G and unbalance Pu: (8)P=G+Pu

In the rotating coordinate system the unbalance is constant, and its components in directions xr,2 and xr,3 are, as follows: (9)Pu,r,2=mrɛΩ2cos(β), Pu,r,3=mrɛΩ2sin(β) where β is the angle between the crack and unbalance vector, and ɛ is the eccentricity of rotor elements.

On the other hand, the vector of gravity G rotates around the axis of the rotor with its angular speed Ω and its components in the local coordinate system are, as follows: (10)Gr,2=mrgcos(Ωt), Gr,3=mrgsin(Ωt) where g is gravity acceleration.

sec.title: 2.2. State–space representation of the uncracked rotor
sec.p: Applying state–space notation, motion equations (1) can be presented as: (11){x·=Ax+Buy=Cx+Du with n×n dimensional system matrix A, n×nu dimensional control inputs matrix B, ny×n dimensional measurement outputs matrix C, and zero matrix D. Here, x denotes the n-dimensional state vector of the following form: (12)x=[q1Tq2T…qrT…qnrT,q·1Tq·2T…q·rT…q·nrT] consisting of 6nr displacement and 6nr velocity variables, where nr is the number of RFEs (i.e. n=564), nu denotes the number of control inputs, and ny is the number of measurement outputs of the system. Since the only forces applied to the rotor are unbalance Pu and gravity G, then u=P=Pu+G, and nu=1 in this case. The vibrations of the rotor are measured by four proximity probes, hence ny=4. Matrices A, B, C are given by (13)A=[0,I-M-1K,-M-1(Dd+ΩDg)],B=[0-M-1], C=[CxCv] where Cx, Cv denote matrices representing sensors’ locations measuring displacements and velocities of mass centers of selected rigid finite elements, I and 0 are the identity and zero matrices of the proper sizes. In the considered case Cv=0 and (14)Cx=[00…C8…0…C37…0] where the non-zero elements of the 4×6 matrices C8 and C37 are, as follows (15)C8(1,2)=1, C8(2,3)=1, C37(3,2)=1, and C37(4,3)=1 since no velocities but displacements of the 8th and 37th RFEs along axes xr,2 and xr,3 are only measured (Figure 1(b)).
The state–space form, equation (11) is extended in Section 3.1, where the formulation of the robust fault detection filter is yielded.

sec.title: 2.3. Model of the crack
sec.p: Usually, the shaft crack is modeled by periodic stiffness changes, resulting from the breathing mechanism, i.e. from the periodical opening and closing of the crack due to the rotational motion of the rotor. Hinge models were the first, which included the breathing of the crack by introducing two different states: the completely open and the completely closed crack at particular angular positions of the rotor (Grabowski, 1984; Gasch, 1993). Mayes and Davies (1984) introduced the model, in which the changes from the completely open to the completely closed state were governed by a continuous function, the crack steering function. Usually, this function takes the form of a simple cosine function depending on the torsional angle.

Progressive development of the finite element method and its application to rotordynamics analysis resulted in the very sophisticated crack models in which fracture mechanics methods were applied. A commonly used approach was presented by Darpe et al. (2004), who derived the 12×12 stiffness matrix of the cracked finite element and developed an original model of the crack breathing.

Darpe et al. (2004) evaluate the extent of crack opening/closing by calculating the stresses at selected points along the crack edge line. If these stresses are positive, then the given portion of the cracked surface is supposed as compressed. This situation corresponds to the partially closed crack. However, if the stresses are negative, then the cracked surface at this point of the crack edge is in the tensile state, resulting in a partially open crack. The method proposed by Darpe et al. (2004) has been successfully applied for numerous calculations of the breathing mechanism, yet it is rather complicated and time-consuming as the values of integrals for flexibilities, of complex formulas for stress intensity factors, etc. must be calculated in each time step. Furthermore, many researchers (Vare and Andrieux, 2005; Bachschmid et al., 2008) claim that the concept of the crack closure line proposed by Darpe et al. does not reflect the real behavior of the breathing crack and that the true breathing mechanism should be introduced (Vare and Andrieux, 2005). Using this approach, the open and closed areas of the crack cross-section are determined by calculating the compressive stresses not at selected points of the crack edge line but at each point of the cracked cross-section. Though such a technique predicts the breathing mechanism very accurately, it is even more time-consuming than the previous technique.

The present paper introduces a new model of the crack (Figure 3). The crack is located between the 24th and the 25th RFE and the idea is to use several spring-damping elements connecting these two rigid finite elements, and modeling the breathing behavior. Figure 3.
Model of the crack. (a) A portion of the rotor at the location of the crack, (b) the two rigid finite elements and several spring-damping elements modeling the crack, (c) shaft cross section at the crack location.

The 24th SDE (marked with a big crossed circle in Figure 3(b)) is located at the geometrical center of the uncracked area. The 6×6 block of stiffness coefficients K24 of this SDE is assumed proportionally to the relative depth of the uncracked area: (16)K24=(1-μ)K24,u where μ=a2R is the relative depth of the crack, R is the radius of the shaft, K24,u is the block of stiffness coefficients of the SDE, which would connect the two RFEs in case of the uncracked shaft. Thus, block K24,u is calculated for the uncracked shaft in a usual way, according to the procedure described in (Kruszewski et al., 1999; Wittbrodt et al., 2006).

The cracked area between the two RFEs is connected with several smaller SDEs. There are 19 SDEs in Figure 3(c)), yet in practical calculations, the number of small SDEs should be chosen in a way that ensures the realistic opening and closing of the crack. These SDEs are located at selected points of the uncracked area, e.g. at the nodes of the imaginary geometrical array, formed with vertical and horizontal lines running perpendicularly and parallel to the crack edge. Blocks of stiffness coefficients Kk of the individual SDEs are equal and are chosen in such a way that their sum is proportional to the relative depth of the crack (17)∑k=4949+ncKk=μK24,u where nc is the number of small SDEs. Hence, the sum of the stiffness coefficients of small SDEs Kk and the big SDE K24 equals the stiffness of the uncracked SDE (18)K24+∑k=4949+ncKk=K24,u

The situation described above illustrates the fully closed crack state. If crack breathing is to be accounted for, then the stiffness of small SDEs should change. In practice, these changes are determined in a way presented below.

It is assumed, that the block of stiffness coefficients of an individual small SDE can be zero or Kk depending on the deformation vector Δwk, which for the k-th SDE is calculated as follows (Kruszewski et al., 1999; Wittbrodt et al., 2006): (19)Δwk=Tr,kqr-Tp,kqp where qr and qp are vectors of displacements of the r-th and p-th RFEs connected with the k-th SDE, and Tr,k and Tp,k are transformation matrices defined in Kruszewski et al. (1999) and Wittbrodt et al. (2006).

In fact, the whole vector Δwk is not taken into consideration but its first component Δwk,1 along axis yk,1, i.e. along the axis of the shaft. If Δwk,1 is greater than zero, then the corresponding SDE is compressed, its stiffness block should be Kk≠0 and the crack at this location is closed. It can be vividly presented, as if the spring-damper touches the crack surface (Figure 4). On the other hand if Δwk,1 is less or equal to zero, then the corresponding SDE is under tension, its stiffness should be zero and the crack at this location is opened. It can be presented as if the spring-damper does not touch the surface of the crack. This way, based on the sign of the deformation of all small SDEs in a direction perpendicular to the crack surface, the extent of the crack opening can be easily determined, and the corresponding stiffness changes can be introduced into the global stiffness matrix. Figure 4.
Possible axial deformations of the small spring-damping elements. (a) Compression, (b) tension.

sec.title: 3. Design of the robust fault detection filter
3.1. Problem formulation
sec.p: The robust fault detection filter is formulated for the linear time invariant dynamic system given by the following state-space equation (Peng et al., 2005; Ding, 2008) (20){x·=Ax+Bu+Edd+Effy=Cx+Du+Fdd+Fff

When compared to equation (11), equation (20) is extended by additional input vectors d and f of lengths nd and nf respectively, and the corresponding matrices Ed, Ef, Fd and Ff. Vector d denotes the vector of unknown inputs, including disturbance, uninterested faults, noise or structure uncertainty. Vector f is the vector of faults to be detected. Matrices Ed, Fd indicate the places where disturbances affect the system and the level of their influence. Similarly, matrices Ef, Ff indicate the places where faults occur and their influence on the system components. Signals d and f are assumed to be L2 norm bounded (Peng et al., 2005). The following assumptions are also applied (Peng et al., 2005):
(A1) (C,A) is detectable,
(A2) [A-jωIEdCFd] has full row rank for all ω.

sec.title: 3.2. Residual generation
sec.p: As stated previously, a model-based fault detection procedure runs in the following two steps: residual generation and residual evaluation. The residual generator is constructed as a linear full-order output observer (21){∧·x=Ax∧+Bu+L(y-y∧)y∧=Cx∧+Dur=Δy=y-y∧=y-Cx∧-Du where x∧, y∧ represent the state and output estimation vectors, respectively, r is the residual signal, and L is the observer gain matrix, which is the design parameter. Let e=x-x∧, which denotes the state estimation error. Then, the error dynamics of observer (21) and the residual are yielded by (22){e·=A∧e+E∧dd+E∧ffr=Ce+Fdd+Fff where A∧=A-LC, E∧d=Ed-LFd, E∧f=Ef-LFf.

The dynamics of the residual generator can be also presented, as (23)r(s)=rd(s)+rf(s)=Trd(s)d(s)+Trf(s)f(s) where transfer matrices Trd(s) and Trf(s) are defined, as (24)Trd(s)=C(sI-A∧)-1E∧d+Fd
(25)Trf(s)=C(sI-A∧)-1E∧f+Ff

The influence of the model uncertainty as well as unknown inputs d on the residual r is characterized by the H∞ norm (Peng, et al., 2005) (26)H∞=||Trd||∞=supωσ¯(Trd(jω)) where σ¯(·) denotes the maximum singular value of matrix Trd. Robustness performance index of fault detection system is then formulated by (Boyd et al., 1994) (27)H∞≤γ ⇔ ∫0trdTrddt≤γ2∫0tdTd dt, γ→min where γ represents the worst-case criterion for the effect of unknown inputs d on the residual r. The smaller γ is, the more robust the generator becomes and the more unknown inputs are restrained.

The effect of faults on residual is measured by H- index (Hou and Patton, 1996): (28)H-=infωσ¯(Trf(jω)) where σ¯(·) stands for the minimum singular value of matrix Trf. It should be noted that H- is not a norm, since it does not fulfill all conditions of the norm, e.g. the triangle inequality (Wang et al., 2007; Ding, 2008).

Sensitivity performance index of the fault detection system is formulated by (29)H-≥β ⇔ ∫0trfTrfdt≥β2∫0tfTf dt, β→max where β is the worst-case sensitivity measurement of fault from f to r. The larger β is, the more sensitive the generator becomes and the more detectable fault information residual is effected on.
Note that σ¯(·) is always zero when Ff=0 or Ff is not of full column rank (i. e. when rank (Ff)<ny). Thus, Ff should be selected in a way ensuring its full column rank (Peng et al., 2005).

From equation (22) it is obvious that the dynamics of the residual depends not only on faults f but also on disturbances d. Thus, the problem of designing the mixed H-/H∞ fault detection filter can be described as calculating an optimal matrix L such, that matrix A∧=A-LC is asymptotically stable and the generated residual is as sensitive as possible to fault f and as robust as possible to unknown input d.

sec.title: 3.3. Mixed H-/H∞ optimization
sec.p: In this section the procedure of calculating the RFDF gain matrix L is discussed. First, the LMI formulations for separate solutions of conditions (27) and (29) are presented. Next, the iterative optimization algorithm for the mixed H-/H∞ fault detection filter design is introduced.

Based on the bounded real lemma (Boyd et al., 1994; Peng et al., 2005), the H∞ norm of the transfer matrix function Trd from disturbances d to residual r is less or equal to γ (condition (27)) if there exists scalar γ≥γmin, matrix Lγ, and symmetric matrix P>0, such that error system (22) is asymptotically stable and the following LMI holds (Peng et al., 2005; Guo et al., 2009) (30)(ATP+PA+CTC-LγC-CTLγT,PEd-LγFd+CTFdEdTPT-FdTLγT+FdTC,-γ2I+FdTFd)≤0 with γ2I-FdTFd>0. Then, the observer gain matrix is given by L=P-1Lγ and γmin>0 is the minimum of γ which satisfies equation (30).

Similarly, the H- performance index of the transfer matrix function Trf from faults f to residual r is greater or equal to β equation (29) if there exists scalar β≤βmax, matrix Lβ, and symmetric matrix Q, such that system (22) is asymptotically stable and the following LMI holds (Peng et al., 2005; Guo et al., 2009) (31)(-ATQ-QA+CTC+LβC+CTLβT,-QEf+LβFf+CTFf-EfTQT+FfTLβT+FfTC,-β2I+FfTFf)≥0 with β2I-FfTFf<0. In this case, the observer gain matrix is given by L=Q-1Lβ and βmax>0 is the maximum of β which satisfies equation (31).

Combining the above two conditions it has been proved (Peng et al., 2005) that the observer-based mixed H-/H∞ fault detection problem is solved only if there exist scalars β>γ>0 (β≤βmax, γ≥γmin), matrices Lγ, Lβ and P>0, Q>0, such that system (22) is asymptotically stable, P-1Lγ=Q-1Lβ, as well as both LMIs (30) and (31) hold. Furthermore, the optimal gain matrix L is obtained by solving the following optimization problem (Peng et al., 2005): (32)minJsubject to(27)and(29) where (33)J=γ/β

Based on this, the iterative optimization algorithm for the calculation of the observer gain matrix L of the mixed H-/H∞ fault detection filter has been developed in (Peng et al., 2005). Here, this algorithm is modified in a way ensuring the reduction of the iteration steps required for finding the solution. For this purpose, some steps that are originally solved by iterative calculations (Peng et al., 2005), are replaced by the specially formulated LMIs. The modified algorithm is, as follows:
Set γ2=γ2>0 and β2=β2>0. Minimize γ2 and maximize β2 to find feasible solutions of LMIs (30) and (31). Calculate γmin and βmax as γmin=γ2 and βmax=β2 respectively. Set γj=βmax, where the iteration number j=0.
Solve LMI (30) to find feasible solutions Pj and Lγ,j. Substitute Lβ,j=QjLj and β2,j=βj2>0 into (31), where Lj=Pj-1Lγ,j. Maximize β2,j to find feasible solution Qj of LMI (31). Calculate βj as βj=β2,j. Log the obtained values of γj, βj and Lj.
Increase the iteration number; set j=j+1. Decrease γ by some small adjustable parameter εγ>0, i. e. set γj=γj-1-εγ. If γj>γmin then go to step 2, otherwise continue to step 4.
Set βj=γmin and j=0.
Solve LMI (31) to find feasible solutions Qj and Lβ,j. Substitute Lγ,j=PjLj and γ2,j=γj2>0 into equation (30), where Lj=Qj-1Lβ,j. Minimize γ2,j to find feasible solution Pj of LMI (30). Calculate γj as γj=γ2,j. Log the obtained values of γj, βj and Lj.
Increase the iteration number; set j=j+1. Increase β by some small adjustable parameter εβ>0, i. e. set βj=βj-1+εβ. If βj<βmax then go to step 5, otherwise continue to step 7.
For all logged values of γj and βj obtained in steps 2 and 5 calculate J=γ/β, equation (33).The H-/H∞ optimized observer gain is found as the logged Lj corresponding to the minimum of J.

When compared to the original procedure, suggested in Peng et al. (2005), the present algorithm introduces scalars β2,j and γ2,j instead of their corresponding squares into conditions (30) and (31) in steps 2 and 5. Consequently, conditions (30) and (31) are transformed from the bilinear into the linear matrix inequalities which can be easily solved for the minimized γ and maximized β.

sec.title: 3.4. Residual evaluation
sec.p:
After designing the fault detection filter, the remaining task is the evaluation of the generated residual. One of the widely adopted approaches is to choose a so called threshold Jth>0 and based on this use the following logical relationship for fault detection (34)||r||2,T>Jth⇒system with fault⇒alarm
(35)||r||2,T≤Jth⇒no faults where the so-called residual generation function ||r||2,T is determined by (36)||r||2,T=∫t1t2rTr dt=||rd+rf||2,T,T=t2-t1 and rd and rf are defined as follows: rd=r|f=0, rf=r|d=0. Thus the threshold Jth can be chosen, as Jth=Jth,d=supd||rd||2,T.

sec.title: 3.5. Application to the tested rotor
sec.p: The application of the described robust fault detection filter for the rotor under consideration requires that the state–space model, equation (11) is extended by disturbances and faults distribution matrices Ed, Fd, Ef, Ff, according to equation (20).

For the purposes of the present study it is assumed that the only disturbances affecting the rotor are noises disturbing the measurements at the locations of displacement sensors. There are four proximity probes measuring rotor lateral displacements at the centers of the 8th and the 37th RFEs (i.e. ny=4, see section 2.2 and Figure 1(b)). It is assumed that the output signals of these probes may be disturbed by random-noise signals of the proper standard deviation. Hence, Fd which defines the distribution of the sensor disturbances is taken as the 4×4 identity matrix, i.e. (37)Fd=I

The other disturbances, such as environmental disturbances, unexpected changes within the rotor as well as the inner rotor noises are not taken into consideration. Thus, matrix Ed which defines the distribution of the inner disturbances within the rotor model is taken as zero, i.e. (38)Ed=0

For the faults distribution it is assumed that the only fault that can occur in the considered system is the shaft crack between the 24th and 25th RFE (Figure 1(b)). Matrix Ef can be derived from the following argument.

The breathing mechanism described in Section 2.3 can be presented by general periodic changes in the global stiffness matrix K. Indeed, the changes in stiffness coefficient blocks of individual SDEs connecting the 24th and 25th RFEs are transformed through the corresponding matrices Tr,k, Tp,k (equation (19)) to the proper locations in the global stiffness matrix K. Hence, the equations of motion, equation (1) of the cracked rotor can be presented in the following, well-known form (Gasch, 1993; Friswell and Penny, 2002; Sawicki et al., 2003) (39)Mq··+(Dd+ΩDg)q·+(Ku-ΔKcf(t))q=P where Ku is the stiffness of the uncracked rotor, ΔKc is some difference between the stiffness of the uncracked and cracked rotor, and the form of the general function f(t) is determined as described in Section 2.3. Equation (39) can be reformulated, as (40)Mq··+(Dd+ΩDg)q·+Kuq=P+ΔKcf(t)q or (41)Mq··+(Dd+ΩDg)q·+Kuq=P+Pc where Pc=ΔKc f(t)q can be seen as a vector of additional forces influencing the shaft due to the crack. Because of the structure of matrix ΔKc, the structure of vector Pc is, as follows: (42)Pc=[00…0Pc,24TPc,25T0…0]T where some elements of the 6×1 vectors Pc,24 and Pc,25 are non-zeros. Thus the breathing behavior of the crack can be generally described by some additional forces influencing the 24th and the 25th RFE. To simplify, it can be assumed that the appearance of only one force, e.g. the force influencing the 24th RFE along axis x2 is the symptom of the fault. Let us denote this single force as Pf. Then Pc can be presented in the following form (43)Pc=[00…0Pc,24T00…0]T with Pc,24=[0Pf0000]T
Applying the state–space notation and including equation (41), state–space equations (11) can be presented, as (44)x·=Ax+Bu+Ef*f with f=[0Pc] and Ef=[0-M-1].
Assuming equation (43), equation (44) can be reformulated, as (45)x·=Ax+Bu+EfPf where (46)Ef=[0-M-1Bf] with (47)Bf=[00…Bf,24T0…0]T and the 6×1 matrix Bf,24=[010000]T.
Hence, the appearance of the additional force Pf influencing the 24th RFE along axis x2 is assumed as the only symptom of the fault and the structure of matrix Ef is clear.

The remaining matrix of the extended state–space model, equation (20) is Ff, which describes the faults within sensors or the indirect influence of the faults on the measurement signals. Since this matrix cannot be zero (see Section 3.2) it has been assumed in the following form: (48)Ff=gf[1111]T indicating the direct transfer of the fault Pf to all four proximity probes. Gain gf has been evaluated during preliminary numerical analysis as gf=10, ensuring the required condition 0<γmin<βmax.

sec.title: 3.6. Rotor model reduction
sec.p: For the purposes of the robust fault detection filter design, the order of the rotor model, equation (11), should be reduced. This is due to large dimensions of system matrices (n=564 in the considered case), resulting in big memory demands as well as difficult and very time-consuming numerical calculations. The other advantage of model reduction is minimizing the order of the RFDF itself, as an important factor if hardware implementation of its algorithm is considered.

Equations of motion (1) are reduced by the modal truncation approach (Friswell, 1990) assuming the lightly damped system and neglecting gyroscopic effects. The reduced global system matrices and vectors of the system are yielded, as (49)qR=TRq,MR=TRTMTR,DdR=TRTDdTR,DgR=TRTDgTR,KR=TRTKTR,PR=TRTP with the transformation matrix TR, composed of the nR lower eigenvectors of the system (50)TR=[Φ1Φ2…ΦnR] where nR is the required order of the reduced system. The reduction procedure involves the calculation of the eigenvectors Φi of the undamaged system as (51)(-ω0iM+K)Φi=0 where ω0i and Φi are the i-th natural frequency and mode shape.
Reduced system matrices MR, DdR, DgR, KR and vectors qR, PR are then used in the formulation of the state–space models (11) and (20) during the design of the RFDF.

The rotor model has been reduced to the 6th order, i.e. nR=6. The results of the numerical and experimental analysis presented in Sections 5 and 6 confirm that this is enough for the purposes of the RFDF design. Figure 5 shows the frequency characteristics of the full and reduced model for the selected input and output. A good agreement for the first two natural frequencies is evident. Figure 5.
Frequency responses of the reduced and full-order model.

sec.title: 4. Numerical results
sec.p:
The calculations were conducted for the rotor made of steel of Young’s modulus E=2.08×1011 Pa, Poisson's ratio ν=0.3 and density ρ=7850 kg/m3. The values of the radial bearings’ stiffness and damping were assumed as kB=3.6×106 N/m, and dB=10 Ns/m. After assembling the rigid finite element model of the uncracked rotor, the natural frequencies and the Campbell diagram were calculated. The first two bending natural frequencies are located at 36.6 Hz and 212 Hz (Figure 6). Figure 6.
Cambell diagram of the uncracked rotor.

Then, the full-order rotor model was reduced to the 12th order state–space model (Section 3.6) and the robust fault detection filter was designed (Sections 3.3 and 3.4). The mixed H-/H∞ optimization was conducted using the Yalmip (Löfberg, 2004) and SeDuMi (Sturm, 1999) Matlab toolboxes. At first γmin=0.0281 and βmax=0.3535 were obtained. Following the next steps of the iterative algorithm (Section 3.3), these values were optimized to γ=0.0282 and β=0.3529 ensuring the minimal value of J=γ/β (which is Jmin=0.0798, equation (33)) and the optimal observer gain L (equation (21)). During the iterations the values of γ and β were changed gradually with εγ=εβ=10-4. The results of the optimization are shown in Figure 7, which presents the values of J for subsequent iteration steps. Figure 7.
Results of the optimization algorithm.

Next, the full-order rotor model was extended by the model of the crack (Section 2.3). First of all, time simulations of the vibrations for three different rotors were conducted: the first rotor with no crack, the second with a 25% deep crack and the third with a 40% deep crack. The number of small spring-damping elements connecting the 24th and the 25th elements of the shaft was: nc=260 for the 25% deep crack and nc=488 for the 40% deep crack. The rotor rotated with the angular speed of Ω=27 Hz (1620 rpm), the eccentricity ɛ was assumed as ɛ=3×10-5 m, and the angle β between the crack and unbalance vector as β=0. Equations of motion (1) were integrated using the Newmark integration scheme (Newmark, 1959) untill the 1000th revolution (the stable response) was reached.

In order to assess the robustness of the designed fault detection filter the calculated vibrations were altered by adding some disturbances. The displacements were disturbed by the randomly generated signal with normal Gaussian distribution σ. Three different values of σ were used, namely σ=10-6 m, σ=1.5×10-5 m and σ=5×10-5 m. Then, the disturbed rotor displacements were introduced into the inputs of the designed RFDF and its outputs, i. e. the residual and its evaluation were calculated.

Figure 8(a) presents the vertical displacements of the uncracked rotor measured at the center of the 7th RFE, near the left bearing (see Figure 1(b)). The displacements of the cracked rotor are presented in Figure 8(b), where five different situations are considered. The rotor displacements are divided into five periods and consist of five different responses of the uncracked (0%), the 25% deep (25%) and the 40% deep cracked rotor. The considerable increase in the vibration amplitude caused by the crack is observed. Certainly, Figure 8(b) is not the result of any simulated history of the cracking rotor but it was created artificially by gluing five different simulation results together. In both cases, Figure 8(a) and 8(b), the rotor response was disturbed with the randomly generated signal of standard distribution σ=10-6 m. Figure 8.
Simulated vertical vibration disturbed with the random signal of standard deviation σ=10-6 m. (a) Uncracked rotor, (b) cracked rotor.

To assess the quality of the RFDF design, the compiled responses from Figure 8(b) were introduced into the inputs of three different RFDFs. The first RFDF was designed with the gain matrix L obtained for γmin=0.0281, the second with L obtained for βmax=0.3535 and the third with the optimal L obtained for γ=0.0282 and β=0.3529. According to conditions presented in Section 3.2, the first RFDF should ensure the best attenuation of disturbances with less sensitivity to faults, the second RFDF should ensure the best amplification of faults with less robustness to disturbances, and the third RFDF should ensure the optimal trade-off between the robustness to disturbances and sensitivity to faults.

Figure 9 presents the outputs of the first two fault detection filters. In both cases the values of residual generation function ||r||2,T are less than the calculated threshold Jth in periods where the response of the uncracked rotor is considered. In other cases, i. e. when the response of the cracked rotor is taken into consideration, the values of ||r||2,T are considerably greater than Jth. The above observations agree very well with conditions (34), (35), where the values of ||r||2,T greater than Jth indicate the damaged rotor while the same values less than Jth indicate the undamaged rotor. When compared with the RFDF designed with γmin (Figure 9(a)) the response ||r||2,T of the RFDF designed with βmax (Figure 9(b)) is smaller and much more noisy. This confirms the characteristics of both designs – the first RFDF is more robust to disturbances than the other. Figure 9.
Residual generation function ||r||2,T and threshold Jth for two different RFDFs designed with (a) γmin=0.0281, (b) βmax=0.3535; simulated vertical vibration disturbed with the random signal of standard deviation σ=10-6 m.

Figure 10 presents the output of the third fault detection filter. This RFDF is the optimal design and it should be simultaneously robust to disturbances and sensitive to faults. It is obvious that this requirement is met. Furthermore, conditions (34), (35) are fulfilled, too. Note that the response of this filter is very close to the response of the first one, indicating the possibility to use the simplified design procedure here, namely H∞ design scheme only. Figure 10.
Residual generation function ||r||2,T and threshold Jth for the H-/H∞ optimized robust fault detection filter designed with γ=0.0282, β=0.3529; simulated vertical vibration of the cracked rotor disturbed with the random signal of standard deviation σ=10-6 m.

Figure 11 presents the same responses as Figure 8 but disturbed with the random signal with standard deviation σ=1.5×10-5 m. This time, the difference in amplitude between the cracked and uncracked rotor response in Figure 11(b) is not so obvious and it could be easily omitted or recognized as some other disturbation. However, the responses of the RFDF still indicate the presence of the crack (Figure 12). For the cracked rotor the values of ||r||2,T are considerably greater than the calculated threshold Jth, though much more noisy if compared with those from Figure 10. The results presented in Figure 12 and hereafter were obtained for the RFDF designed with the optimal gain matrix L calculated with γ=0.0282 and β=0.3529. Figure 11.
Simulated vertical vibration disturbed with the random signal of standard deviation σ=1.5×10-5 m. (a) Uncracked rotor, (b) cracked rotor.
Figure 12.
Residual generation function ||r||2,T and threshold Jth for the H-/H∞ optimized robust fault detection filter designed with γ=0.0282, β=0.3529; simulated vertical vibration of the cracked rotor disturbed with the random signal of standard deviation σ=1.5×10-5 m.

If much more noise and disturbance is present in the response of the rotor (Figure 13) then the RFDF responds with the weak and noisy residual signal (Figure 14). This time the standard deviation of the disturbance was σ=5×10-5 m. It would be almost impossible to detect the crack (the residual is below the threshold) in such a noisy environment. Figure 13.
Simulated vertical vibration disturbed with the random signal of standard deviation σ=5×10-5 m. a) Uncracked rotor, (b) cracked rotor.
Figure 14.
Residual generation function ||r||2,T and threshold Jth for the H-/H∞ optimized robust fault detection filter designed with γ=0.0282, β=0.3529; simulated vertical vibration of the cracked rotor disturbed with the random signal of standard deviation σ=5×10-5 m.

The experiments conducted so far confirm the very good sensitivity of the designed fault detection filter to crack symptoms even in the noisy rotor vibration response. However, only the very deep cracks were tested. Figure 15(b) presents vertical vibrations of the rotor with a 2% deep crack and with a 5% deep crack. The number of small spring-damping elements connecting the 24th and the 25th elements of the shaft was: nc=11 for the 2% deep crack and nc=30 for the 5% deep crack. The standard deviation of the disturbation signal was σ=4×10-6 m. Because of disturbations, the changes in the rotor response due to the crack are almost invisible (Figure 15(b)). However, if the response of the robust fault detection filter is considered, then the appearance of the crack is self-evident (Figure 16). It is obvious that even for shallow cracks and in the presence of disturbations the designed RFDF generates reliable crack signatures. Figure 15.
Simulated vertical vibration disturbed with the random signal of standard deviation σ=0.4×10-6 m. (a) Uncracked rotor, (b) cracked rotor.
Figure 16.
Residual generation function ||r||2,T and threshold Jth for the H-/H∞ optimized robust fault detection filter designed with γ=0.0282, β=0.3529; simulated vertical vibration of the cracked rotor disturbed with the random signal of standard deviation σ=0.4×10-6 m.

sec.title: 5. Experimental results
sec.p:
The rigid finite element model of the cracked rotor as well as the designed robust fault detection filter were tested and validated experimentally. Figure 17 presents vertical vibrations of the rotor measured near the left bearing at the center of the 7th RFE (see Figure 1(b)). The results of the experiment are denoted with the solid lines and the dotted lines denote the results of the simulation. The vibrations of the uncracked rotor, of the 25% deep cracked rotor, and of the 40% deep cracked rotor are shown in subsequent plots of Figure 17. The simulation plots are the zoomed portions of subsequent areas of the plot presented in Figures 8(b), 11(b) or 13(b) but with no disturbances. A very good agreement between the experimental and simulation results is evident; only the amplitudes of the 40% deep cracked rotor differ a little. Furthermore, some disturbances and noise are present in the experimental results. The noise is generated mainly in the eddy current proximity probes. The disturbances may be due to some bearings imperfections, misalignment, etc. Figure 17.
Vertical vibration of the rotor. (a) With no crack, (b) with the 25% deep crack, (c) with the 40% deep crack; solid line: experiment; dotted line: simulation.

Figures 18, 19 and 20 present the vibration frequency spectra of the uncracked, of the 25% deep cracked, and of the 40% deep cracked rotor, respectively. The frequency responses in these three cases consist only of the synchronous frequency 27 Hz (denoted as 1X), which is the rotating speed, and of its integer multiples, denoted as 2X (54 Hz), 3X (81 Hz), 4X (108 Hz), etc. Only the changes in the amplitude of the 1X and 2X frequencies can be used as possible symptoms of the crack, which corresponds well with the earlier observations (Bently and Muszynska, 1986; Saavedra and Cuitino, 2002), yet they are small and can be easily overlooked. A very good agreement between experimental and simulation results can be observed, though there is less leakage in the simulation response. It is well known (Sawicki et al., 2008, 2011) that some multiples of the synchronous frequency may appear in the frequency response of the uncracked rotor (Figure 18(b)). Such multiples are not present if the simulation results are considered (Figure 18(a)). The explanation for the above is such that there are always some nonlinearities in the real rotor behavior which result in the multiples in the frequency response. These nonlinearities may be due to misalignment, bearings faults, etc. which are unavoidable in real rotating systems. The simulation model of the uncracked rotor is strictly linear and that is why there is only one component in the vibration spectrum (Figure 18(a)). Figure 18.
Vertical vibration spectrum of the uncracked rotor. (a) Simulation, (b) experiment.
Figure 19.
Vertical vibration spectrum of the 25% cracked rotor: (a) Simulation, b) experiment.
Figure 20.
Vertical vibration spectrum of the 40% cracked rotor. (a) Simulation, (b) experiment.

Figure 21 shows the vibration response of the uncracked and of the cracked rotor obtained experimentally. Similar to Figure 8(b), the results presented in Figure 21(b) are composed of five different periods, representing the responses of the uncracked, of the 25% deep cracked, and of the 40% deep cracked rotor. The experimental results in Figure 21(b) agree very well with the simulation results presented in Figure 8(b). Figure 21.
Measured vertical vibration. (a) Uncracked rotor, (b) cracked rotor.

Experimental results from Figure 21 were introduced into the inputs of the designed RFDF to assess its ability to generate the crack indications. The generated threshold and residual are presented in Figure 22. For the uncracked rotor ||r||2,T is less than Jth, while for the cracked rotor there is the opposite situation. This agrees well with conditions (34), (35) and with the simulation results presented in Figure 10. The values of the residual and of the threshold generated for the experimental data (Figure 22) are greater than the results obtained numerically (Figure 10). In particular, the difference in the magnitude ||r||2,T for the 25% deep cracked and for the 40% deep cracked rotor is evident. Nevertheless a good agreement between the simulation and experimental results as well as an excellent ability of the designed RFDF to detect the crack can be confirmed. Figure 22.
Residual generation function ||r||2,T and threshold Jth for the H-/H∞ optimized robust fault detection filter designed with γ=0.0282, β=0.3529; measured vertical vibration.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: Numerical and experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and reliability of the proposed robust fault detection filter as a shaft crack detection tool. For the 25% and 40% deep cracks, the residual evaluation function values are obtained far above the defined threshold values. As demonstrated by the numerical analysis results, the relatively shallow cracks (2% or 5% deep) also generate strong residuals, even in the presence of comparatively high disturbances (i.e., noise). This is in contrast to time-based responses where cracks are hardly detectable. However, the results obtained for the shallow cracks require further experimental testing and verification.

When compared with the ambiguous frequency response analysis, the crack signatures generated by the RFDF are strong and reliable. The only changes observed in the frequency spectra are small amplitude variations regarding the synchronous frequency. In comparison, the residuals generated by the RFDF are noticeably greater than the thresholds, allowing for efficient crack identification.

The results also confirm the effectiveness and accuracy of the rigid finite element model of the cracked rotor. The agreement between the experimental and numerical data is very good. The RFE model can be applied not only for time simulations but also for RFDF design purposes. When compared with the classical finite element method, the RFE modeling approach is simpler and quicker. This ensures a shorter time from the measurements of the geometrical and material properties of the rotor to the fully functional design of the RFDF.

The original RFDF design procedure has been modified by replacing some iterative calculations by specially formulated LMIs resulting in a reduction of iteration steps required for finding the optimal solution. The fault detection filter for identifying a rotor crack can also be effectively designed considering only the H∞ condition, which is evident from the fact that the RFDF performance for the mixed H-/H∞ design is nearly the same as for the single H∞ design. Such an approach would greatly simplify calculations, as only LMIs are required (i.e., hardly no iterative calculations are needed).

An important problem concerning the rotor crack detection is not only how to detect it but also how to locate the crack along the shaft. Bearing in mind a good performance of the designed RFDF and its ability to also detect the crack from the disturbed/noisy measurements, a next attempt can be made to develop a bank of RFDFs in order to determine the crack position. Presumably a great advantage of the RFDFs’ bank will be the required robustness to disturbances as well as the sensitivity to faults. However, this requires further analytical and experimental studies.

As a next step, it is important to consider the practical implementation of the proposed diagnostic method to different rotor types. Although the size of the obtained state–space model is relatively large, it can be easily reduced using modal truncation. The results of the numerical analysis show that this greatly simplifies the calculations while reducing the time and memory demands. The RFDF, based on the reduced rotor model, is fully functional and efficient as confirmed by experiments.

The positive results shown here dictate that further studies are warranted. Future plans include hardware implementation and online testing of the proposed robust fault detection filter as well as its application for finding the crack position.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
